UK

UK PM May's spokesperson said EU's Juncker and May have failed to finalise a deal on terms of Brexit but added that very good progress has been made in Brexit talks, while PM May will return to Brussels on Saturday. In related news, Brexit negotiators will work through the night to finalise the deal and a Sun reporter said If they go well, there could well be a new draft Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration published tomorrow afternoon. UK Chancellor Hammond said Brexit backstop is not a good arrangement and smooth Brexit is worth billions of pounds to the UK, while he added that there might not be a Brexit if lawmakers reject the deal and that markets will react negatively if parliament reject the deal. (Newswires)

Utilities was an underperforming sector today with Duke Energy (DUK), American Electric Power (AEP) and WEC Energy (WEC) all trading lower. subject: US MARKET WRAP â€“ 21st November 2018: Stocks rebound heading into Thanksgiving
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, treasuries down, dollar down, crude up.
* REAR-VIEW: European Commission rejects Italy’s budget, PM May and EU Juncker fail to finalise Brexit deal, US excludes Navarro from Trump-Xi summit, US durables drop, existing home sales rise, Uni of Michigan miss.
* AHEAD: ECB Minutes, SARB Rate Decision, BoE’s Haldane and Saunders Speaking, ECB’s Mersch to speak.

NOTE: Early Market Closures due to Thanksgiving: Thursday the desk will operate a normal service on Thursday until 1800GMT/1200CST, upon which the desk will close and then re-open later at 2200GMT/1600CST for the beginning on the Asia-Pacific session given the US market closures. Friday the desk will operate a normal service on Friday until 1845GMT/1245CST, upon which the desk will close given the US market closures.

* ITALY: The European Commission rejected Italy’s budget on Wednesday and warranted the possibility of an excessive debt procedure against the country. In comments, European Commissioner Moscovici warned that the "very serious" Italy deviation must be corrected while the Eurogroup President said to support a sanction procedure against the region with ministers set to discuss the sanction procedure in December. In response, PM Conte said that the government is convinced its 2019 budget is "excellent" and in the interests of Italy and Europe, while he said to be concerned overt the spread stating that he will respond with reforms. Deputy PM Salvini is looking to continue polite discussions with the EU but will proceed while he believes that EU sanctions can be avoided and similarly Economy Minister Tria said he is convinced the budget guarantees goal of reducing debt to GDP ratio and he remains committed to open dialogue with the EU Commission. UK PM May has met EU

* BREXIT: A spokesperson announced that the PM May and EU’s Juncker have failed to finalise an agreement on the terms of Brexit at their meeting in Brussels on Wednesday, although very good progress was made in talks. Brexit negotiators will work through the night to finalise the deal. As a brief summary to where we stand, effort made by Brexiteers to force a no-confidence vote over PM May seem to have failed for now, with focus now shifting on issues raised by France over fishing rights, Spain over Gibraltar co-sovereignty and all, including Germany, pushing for tougher conditions on the UK after Brexit. Note the Chief Minister of Gibraltar will brief Gibraltar's Parliament on Thursday at 2pm GMT on the status of Brexit negotiations ahead of the Special European Council on Sunday. In earlier comments, a PM May's spokesperson said that negotiations will take as long as needed to get the right deal for the UK and later denied reports suggesting that the EU Special Summit scheduled for Sunday could be called off. Elsewhere, Irish PM Varadkar said that the government has made no plans for a hard border adding that a no-deal scenario would require a deal on regulations and custom union with the UK.

* TRADE: Earlier this morning, the SCMPA announced that the US has reportedly excluded US Trade Advisor Navarro from the Trump-Xi summit while in there were separate reports in the FT suggesting that the G20’s longstanding call to resist trade protectionism is in the balance ahead of the Argentina summit. Additionally, the WTO are to set up a dispute panel to rule on US complaint against China over IP rights; China contested "false claims" made by the US in the IP complaints at the meeting telling the WTO that those complaints lack credibility.

* GEOPOLITICS: US Defence Secretary Mattis said he will reduce the scope of military exercise with South Korea to ensure the exercises will not be harmful to diplomatic efforts. Note the annual joint military drills between South Korea and US have caused friction with China and North Korea in the past.

* US DURABLES fell by 4.4% in October significantly more than the expected 2.5% and the largest fall since October 2017. September gains were also swept away by revisions. Looking at the breakdown, volatility in the aircraft and defence sectors have contributed to the headline weakness. Non-defence capital goods orders posted flat, with the last monthly increase seen in July, with the “three-month average annualized growth rate is now the lowest since March” Wells Fargo notes. Looking ahead, Wells Fargo expects “business equipment spending to bounce back in Q4 after a weak Q3 but for the pace to be below the robust rates seen in H1-2018”.

* EXISTING HOME SALES rose to 5.22mln from 5.15mln and slightly above the 5.20mln expectations. The uptick in sales is consistent with the message conveyed by pending home sales in September; hurricanes have depressed activity relative to mortgage applications’ trend. Analysts at Pantheon expect a rebound in the coming months, up to the end of the year, but do stress that the housing market is slowing down, amid higher interest rates and more severe lending standard, but “broad declines are very unlikely”.

* SPX +0.3% at 2650, NDX +0.8% at 6576, DJI -0.0% at 24464. SECTORS: Energy +1.6%, Materials +0.8%, Industrials +0.7%, Cons Discretionary +1.0%, Cons Staples -0.8%, Healthcare -0.5%, Financials +0.1%, Tech +0.6%, Telecoms +1.0%, Utilities -1.5%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Footlocker (FL) reported EPS, revenue and same store sales above estimates making it a top mover on the day; FL supplier Nike (NKE) caught a bid on this too. Autodesk (ADSK) and Keysight Technologies (KEYS) traded higher after beating EPS and revenue estimates whilst raising guidance. FAANG stocks rebounded higher today with Facebook (FB) leading the bunch. Utilities was an underperforming sector today with Duke Energy (DUK), American Electric Power (AEP) and WEC Energy (WEC) all trading lower. Pharmaceutical stocks Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Eli Lilly (LLY) were other bottom movers.

* WTI (F9) SETTLES $1.20 HIGHER AT $54.63; BRENT (F9) SETTLES $0.95 HIGHER AT $63.48. After crude skidded lower on Tuesday, the complex has stabilised; API's weekly energy inventory data provided some support after Tuesday's settlement, where headline crude stocks drew unexpectedly. That, however, was not seen in the official DOE data (Crude +4.851mln vs exp 2.941mln; Cushing -0.116mln; Gasoline -1.295mln vs exp -0.198mln; distillates -0.077mln vs exp -2.754mln; production unchanged in the week). The data was bearish for crude but more positive for products; crude fell after the release, though did find a bid as the Thanksgiving holiday approached and traders left their desks. Traders were passing around a Goldman Sachs note (released late Tuesday), which argued that the crude sell-off has overshot fundamentals, but GS said prices will continue to be highly volatile until fundamentals improve (decline in OPEC production; signs demand growth is resilient; reversal in recent inventory builds).

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 3+ TICKS LOWER AT 119-07+. Volumes and action were light on Wednesday ahead of Thursday Thanksgiving market holiday. After trading lower in Asia, T-Notes ticked up in European trade, but once again found some sellers around the US open, with dealer positioning ahead of the TIPS supply being cited. The bias was for yield curve narrowing, with 2s5s tightening to levels not seen in 11-years+. The Treasury sold USD 11bln of 10-year TIPS, tailing 0.2bps. 

* USD: The Greenback has retreated a bit further from recent peaks, with the DXY dipping below 96.500 at one stage and not helped or enthused by US data/survey misses in the form of weekly claims, durables and Michigan sentiment that together overshadowed firmer than forecast existing home sales and inline leading indicators in the run up to the long holiday weekend.

* NZD, AUD: Consolidating recovery gains vs their US counterpart amidst a broad revival in risk sentiment, with the Kiwi now retesting 0.6850 and Aud extending its rebound to 0.7250+.

* EUR, CAD, GBP: Also benefiting from the Buck’s defensive ahead of Thanksgiving, with the single currency managing to hold around 1.1400 into the NY cut when a decent 1 bn option expiry ran off amidst more Italian vs EU budget disharmony after Brussels officially ruled that the fiscal draft contravened the rules and warranted excessive deficit procedures. Meanwhile, the Loonie resisted significantly weaker than expected Canadian wholesale trade data with the aid of a rebound in crude and other commodity prices to keep its head above 1.3300. Sterling also showed a degree of resilience in the face of ongoing Brexit uncertainty and contradictory headlines on the proviso rather than firm or confident perception that UK PM May returns from Brussels with anything new on the withdrawal proposal front that will sway Parliament doubters to back the proposed divorce settlement.

* CHF, JPY: A degree of divergence between the two renowned safe havens as the Franc retained an element of allure/demand in wake of the aforementioned impasse on Italy’s expansionary plans, while the Jpy suffered more than the Usd as risk appetite resurfaced and struggled to rebound from circa 113.00 levels despite the potential draw of huge option expiries below the big figure.

* EM: Widespread gains vs the retreating Usd, but the Zar and Try outperformed on multiple factors including a marginal consensus for an SARB hike tomorrow and bullish technical as the Lira retested recent highs circa 5.310.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: Gilts edging it, as US data misses keep Usd on edge
content: More sub-consensus US data to digest before the Thanksgiving break, and a further paring of losses in core debt with Bunds edging up to a marginal new Eurex session high of 160.77 (-12 ticks vs -41 ticks at one stage), while Gilts have rebounded even further from worst levels on Liffe to trade in positive territory At 123.14 (+14 ticks vs -28 ticks at the other extreme) and still adopting a defensive or cautious stance amidst all the ongoing Brexit uncertainty. Meanwhile, the Dollar is also treading carefully in the run up to the long holiday weekend, with indications that US equities could regain some composure after Tuesday’s sell-off and on the prospect or premise of a more pragmatic vs pre-determined Fed on further policy normalisation going forward, beyond December. DXY currently midway between 96.487-877 trading parameters.

Elsewhere the co. is in talks with veterans to provide them portable electronic health records, allowing easier healthcare access for veterans and gaining new customers; according to the WSJ. The Information reports that the co. has acquired the AI software co. Silk Labs. (Newswires/WSJ/The Information)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – Kuwait Projects is looking to sell a majority stake in OSN and has tapped Goldman to advise it on the sale. (Newswires)
  • Verizon (VZ) – Verizon’s blogging site Tumblr app has been taken down from Apple’s (APPL) app store reportedly due to “offensive images”. Separately, nine senators have requested accountability from the co. and XPO Logistics (XPO) after several women suffered miscarriages working at an XPO warehouse, shipping Verizon products, in Memphis, Tennessee. (NY Times)

S&P500

  • Albemarle (ALB) – The chemicals co. has entered a JV with Mineral Resources for lithium mining, Albermale’s 50% interest will see it invest USD 1.15bln. (Newswires)
  • FirstEnergy (FE) – The electric co. will sell its West Lorain facility to Starwood Energy, terms not disclosed. (WSJ)
  • Fluor (FLR) – The construction co. has been selected by ioneer Ltd. for a lithium and boron mine project in Nevada, where it will first create a study then provide engineering, procurement and construction management services. (Newswires)
  • United Airlines (UAL) – The airline co. has won a fee dispute against the Port Authority of Ney York and New Jersey, where the FAA said the Port Authority was not transparent with its fees. (WSJ)
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) – The bank is trying to avoid compensation to 600k drivers who purchased car insurance even if they did not need it; according to a source familiar with the matter. (Newswires)

NASDAQ

  • Facebook (FB) – Ad technology was down on the website for some retailers yesterday, just a few days before the crucial Black Friday. Elsewhere, a Russian news agency, whose Facebook page was removed over alleged election meddling, is suing the co. and seeking damages. CEO Mark Zuckerberg told CNN that he does not plan to leave the position as Chairman. TechCrunch reports that COO Sheryl Sandberg denies any part in promoting anti-Semitic content. (Newswires/CNN/TechCrunch)
  • JD.com (JD) – There were reportedly hundreds of students who worked long shifts illegally for the retailer on its Singles Day. (FT)
  • Mylan (MYL) – The pharma co. has voluntarily recalled select lots of Valsartan-containing products after detected trace amounts of an impurity. Separately, earlier in the month the FDA sent a letter to the co. over inadequate cleaning for manufacturing equipment with the drugmaker now addressing the issues.  (Newswires)
  • Nvidia (NVDA) – The chipmaker has entered into separate agreements with start-ups Peng Motors, Singulato Motors and SF Motors for the development of self-driving technology. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Celanese (CE) – The chemicals co. has increased its Fortron polyphenylene sulphide price by USD 0.85/kg. (Newswires)
  • DexCom (DXCM) – The diabetes focused med-tech co. has amended its collaboration and licensing agreement with Alphabet’s (GOOGL) Verily, where DexCom will make a USD 250mln upfront payment with more payments to follow. (Newswires)
  • iQIYI (IQ), Alphabet (GOOGL) – Chinese tech co. iQIYI has partnered with Google for Digital Rights Management. (Newswires)
  • Tencent (TCEHY) – The Chinese tech co is looking at delaying its USD 2bln Music Entertainment IPO from November until early 2019, citing poorer market conditions. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 21st November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities are higher across the board (Eurostoxx 50 +0.8%) as the region stemmed the stock rout seen in Asia and Wall Street
  • European commission has rejected the Italian budget, with the opening of EDP said to be warranted
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Durable Goods, Weekly Jobs, Existing Home Sales, Uni. of Michigan, DoEs, Japanese CPI, BoE’s Carney, UK PM May to meet with EC’s Juncker

ASIA

Asian stocks mostly weakened as the global stock rout continued into the region following the losses in US, where the DJIA dropped over 500 points to turn negative YTD and in which energy names were pressured as oil slumped nearly 7%. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) were led lower by spill-over selling seen across the commodity-related sectors, while Wesfarmers shares plummeted nearly 30% after the spin-off of its Coles unit which had its stock market debut today. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) opened with firm losses but then rebounded off their lows with price action choppy amid ongoing trade uncertainty and after criticism from USTR Lighthizer’s report that China has not altered its unfair practices and appears to have conducted further unreasonable actions in recent months. Finally, 10yr JGBs failed to benefit from the widespread risk averse tone with price action subdued amid a lack of BoJ presence in the bond market and after the weakness in T-notes as US investors closed positions heading in to Thanksgiving.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9499 (Prev. 6.9280)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer released a report regarding China intellectual property and tech transfers which stated that China has not altered its unfair practices, while it added that it appears that China has conducted further unreasonable actions in recent months and that China has made it clear it will not change its policies in response to initial Section 301 action. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi is expected to visit Madrid next week where infrastructure investment is expected to be a topic for discussions. (Newswires)

UK/EU

BBC Political Editor Laura Kuenssberg tweets, Damian Collins says it should be 'relatively straightforward' to get a clause into the agreement that allows us to leave the backstop independently - that might be news to the negotiators but goes on to suggest that another referendum might be the answer if the vote fails. (Twitter)

Regarding PM May's Brexit deal, Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd says that she does not think any of the cabinet are going to vote against it; adding that the House of Commons will stop a no-deal, there is not a majority for that to take place. (BBC)

German Chancellor Merkel says we still don't know how to solve the Spanish objections to the Brexit deal; although she believes a solution will be found by Sunday. (Newswires)

BBC's Katya Adler tweets, Behind the scenes, Germany remains irritated with EU countries like France pushing for tougher conditions on the U.K. in the Brexit deal. Although, Berlin does add that they oppose ‘Chequers through the back door’. (Twitter)

German Government sees no possibility of new negotiations on the Brexit deal. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Salvini could potentially be open to budget revisions (La Stampa) Although, Italy's League denies that Deputy PM Salvini is looking to change the budget, according to sources, (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Salvini says the 2.4% deficit target can't be discussed; adding that he is open to a dialogue on investments but not on the budget or pension reform. Additionally, Salvini says that debt will fall if the economy grows and that the coalition is here to stay. Also, states that the government are convinced by their budget target and will talk about it in a year, believes that EU sanctions can be avoided. (Newswires)

European Commission rejects Italy's budget, as according to Ansa, who add that the European Commission say opening of EDP vs. Italy is warranted. (Newswires) EU Commissions Dombrovsksis adds that the EDP is warranted, with the EU Commission seeing risk of a negative impact on growth from the Italian budget. Also, Belgium. France and Spain are at risk of breaching the budget rules.

Italian 5SM lawmaker D'Uva states that the party will not go back on the budget. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte states that the government remains convinced over their budget and will hold discussions with EC’s Juncker, is also concerned about the spread and the government will respond with reforms. (Newswires)

ISTAT lowers 2018 Italian GDP forecast to 1.1% from 1.4% (made in May), see 2019 at 1.3%; for reference the EU Commission forecasts 2018 growth at 1.1% and 2019 at 1.2%; Italian government forecasts 2019 GDP of 1.5%. (Newswires)

Central Banks

Riksbank's Jochnick says that there's a lot of data to come prior to the December rate decision, there's still a choice between December or February; most recent inflation figure are more or less in line with exp. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board (Eurostoxx 50 +0.8%) as the region stemmed the stock rout seen in Asia and Wall Street. Italy’s FTSE MIB (+0.6%) was initially outperforming with Italian banks higher amid initial reports from Italian press that Deputy PM Salvini could potentially be open to budget revisions, which were later dismissed by League sources ahead of the budget ultimately being rejected. 

In terms of sectors, financial names lost the top spot to telecom names, who are outperforming after French telecoms jumped following comments from Orange (+1.7%) CEO which renewed M&A gossip. Elsewhere, Indivior (-13.6%) fell to the foot of the Stoxx600 (+0.4%) after the Co. lost a US court ruling that had prevented Dr. Reddy’s from selling a generic version of a treatment for opioid addiction.

FX

DXY - The index has maintained its recovery momentum into the midweek session, but is off best levels amidst a welcome reprieve in riskier assets and broad sentiment ahead of Thanksgiving. The DXY has drifted back from another uptick towards 97.000, though remains underpinned ahead of 96.500 and recent lows. The Greenback also retains an underlying bid as G10 and EM counterparts struggle to recoup losses beyond round number/psychological/technical resistance against the backdrop of heavy option expiries at strikes within close proximity to prevailing prices (and with major fundamental issues still prescient of course).

NZD/AUD - The Antipodean Dollars are back in the ascendency as risk aversion seen on Monday and Tuesday abates, and the Yuan rebounds off circa 6.9500 lows vs the Usd after a weaker PBoC midpoint setting overnight and temporary breach of the Cny’s 20 DMA (6.9417). The Kiwi is back above 0.6800 after tripping some stops below late yesterday and the Aud has reclaimed 0.7200+ status as the cross holds continues its recovery/consolidation from sub-1.0600.

EUR/CAD - The single currency is holding up relatively well given more toing and froing on the Italian budget, but ultimately ongoing recalcitrant stance from Rome after reports about potential revisions were renounced in advance of the EU’s official rejection and potential if not probable EDP implementation (scheduled release time 11.00GMT, but appears to have been preannounced). However, 1.1400 is proving almost as obstinate and a decent 1 bn option expiry could well be keeping the headline pair in check. Meanwhile, the Loonie is off worst levels after sliding through 1.3300 and could be gleaning some encouragement from a partial recovery in oil prices in the run up to Canadian wholesale trade data.

GBP/CHF/JPY - All bucking the overall trend, albeit barely in terms of the Pound and Franc, as Cable pivots 1.2800 and Eur/Gbp straddles 0.8900 on Parliament approval aspirations as UK PM May heads to Brussels for more discussions on the Brexit draft and the coup to oust her seems to have fizzled out. Meanwhile, Usd/Chf has only tentatively bounced from near 0.9900 lows within a 0.9935-55 range vs Usd/Jpy back on the 113.00 handle vs a base around 112.30 at one stage on Tuesday when risk-off flows were rife, but bidding interest prevented further downside. Note, a raft of option expiries could be key into the NY cut, stretching from 111.90-112.00 to 114.00 and totalling some 11 bn.

EM - Rand in focus for several reasons, as Usd/Zar hovers near 14.0000 ahead of Thursday’s SARP policy meeting and following softer than expected SA inflation data, with a decent 1.1+ bn options expiring between 13.9000-14.0000 along with speculation about more strike action.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+1.6%) and Brent (+1.4%) took a breather from yesterday’s selloff, where prices fell almost 7% with the decline attributed to supply concerns, negative risk sentiment and Trump’s protective approach to Saudi relations. Prices are underpinned by the latest API inventory data which printed a surprise drawdown in headline crude stockpiles. Traders will be keeping an eye on today’s DoE release for any hints of increased US shale production. Today will also see the release of the EIA natural gas storage data, which has been rescheduled due to the US Thanksgiving Holiday. Elsewhere, the metals complex is in positive territory with gold (+0.2%), silver (+0.7%) and copper (+0.5%) all supported by the pullback in the USD.

Goldman Sachs said slump in oil reflects over supply concerns for 2019 and that technical position factors have exacerbated the volatility, while it also cited low liquidity heading into Thanksgiving as well as broader selling in commodities and cross-assets amid rising growth concerns. (Newswires)

Twitter source noted that a monster storm had shut all of Eastern Canada's crude output but added that one field has now resumed service. (Twitter)

Saudi oil production is said to surge to record levels in early November; Saudi crude output has run at 10.8-10.9mln BPD. With supply having passed 11mln B/D on some days, which includes draw downs from stocks. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Perhaps perversely, or at least against counterintuitively, Italian bonds retain a decent bid in wake of confirmation that the 2019 fiscal draft falls foul of EU rules and will therefore be subject to official measures from Brussels. The 10 year benchmark has actually bounced off a 120.52 low to record a new intraday peak of 121.79 (+148 ticks), as the top brass in Rome remain adamant, albeit intending to discuss the situation further. Hence, safe-haven Bunds, Gilts, and US Treasuries by default are not deriving any real support from spread or hedge positioning and remain below parity, albeit off worst levels (160.48 for Bunds, -41 ticks) despite a well received Bobl auction. However, price action and direction is prone to change or more pronounced volatility with a front-loaded US agenda before Thanksgiving and no guarantee that Wall Street will pick-up the recovery baton.

Meanwhile, Usd/Chf has only tentatively bounced from near 0.9900 lows within a 0.9935-55 range vs Usd/Jpy back on the 113.00 handle vs a base around 112.30 at one stage on Tuesday when risk-off flows were rife, but bidding interest prevented further downside. Note, a raft of option expiries could be key into the NY cut, stretching from 111.90-112.00 to 114.00 and totalling some 11 bn.

EM - Rand in focus for several reasons, as Usd/Zar hovers near 14.0000 ahead of Thursday’s SARP policy meeting and following softer than expected SA inflation data, with a decent 1.1+ bn options expiring between 13.9000-14.0000 along with speculation about more strike action.

FIXED INCOME

Perhaps perversely, or at least against counterintuitively, Italian bonds retain a decent bid in wake of confirmation that the 2019 fiscal draft falls foul of EU rules and will therefore be subject to official measures from Brussels. The 10 year benchmark has actually bounced off a 120.52 low towards 121.00 again, as the top brass in Rome remain adamant, albeit intending to discuss the situation further. Hence, safe-haven Bunds, Gilts, and US Treasuries by default are not deriving any real support from spread or hedge positioning and remain below parity, albeit off worst levels (160.48 for Bunds, -41 ticks) despite a well received Bobl auction. However, price action and direction is prone to change or more pronounced volatility with a front-loaded US agenda before Thanksgiving and no guarantee that Wall Street will pick-up the recovery baton.

COMMODITIES 

WTI (+1.6%) and Brent (+1.4%) took a breather from yesterday’s selloff, where prices fell almost 7% with the decline attributed to supply concerns, negative risk sentiment and Trump’s protective approach to Saudi relations. Prices are underpinned by the latest API inventory data which printed a surprise drawdown in headline crude stockpiles. Traders will be keeping an eye on today’s DoE release for any hints of increased US shale production. Today will also see the release of the EIA natural gas storage data, which has been rescheduled due to the US Thanksgiving Holiday. Elsewhere, the metals complex is in positive territory with gold (+0.2%), silver (+0.7%) and copper (+0.5%) all supported by the pullback in the USD

content:
DXY

 The index has maintained its recovery momentum into the midweek session, but is off best levels amidst a welcome reprieve in riskier assets and broad sentiment ahead of Thanksgiving. The DXY has drifted back from another uptick towards 97.000, though remains firm/underpinned ahead of 96.500 and recent lows. The Greenback also retains an underlying bid as G10 and EM counterparts struggle to recoup losses beyond round number/psychological/technical resistance against the backdrop of heavy option expiries at strikes within close proximity to prevailing prices (and with major fundamental issues still prescient of course).

NZD/AUD

The Antipodean Dollars are back in the ascendency as risk aversion seen on Monday and Tuesday abates, and the Yuan rebounds off circa 6.9500 lows vs the Usd after a weaker PBoC midpoint setting overnight and temporary breach of the Cny’s 20 DMA (6.9417). The Kiwi is back above 0.6800 after tripping some stops below late yesterday and the Aud has reclaimed 0.7200+ status as the cross holds continues its recovery/consolidation from sub-1.0600.

EUR/CAD

The single currency is holding up relatively well given more toing and froing on the Italian budget, but ultimately ongoing recalcitrant stance from Rome after reports about potential revisions were renounced in advance of the EU’s official rejection and potential if not probable EDP implementation (scheduled release time 11.00GMT, but appears to have been preannounced). However, 1.1400 is proving almost as obstinate and a decent 1 bn option expiry could well be keeping the headline pair in check. Meanwhile, the Loonie is off worst levels after sliding through 1.3300 and could be gleaning some encouragement from a partial recovery in oil prices in the run up to Canadian wholesale trade data.

content: Awaiting further Brexit impulses via the next potentially key meeting in Brussels between UK PM May and a top EU official, Gilts and Short Sterling contracts are conforming to the negative tone elsewhere, as anticipated. This is also in acknowledgement of an overall improvement in risk sentiment after Tuesday’s rout, and ahead of the latest snapshot of UK Government finances that are forecast to reveal larger PSNB deficits for the month of October. Also on today’s domestic docket, more commentary from BoE Governor Carney, but highly unlikely to offer anything new on the policy front in wake of yesterday’s lengthy TSC testimony on the QIR that underlined a wait-and-see stance pending the precise details of Britain’s departure from the EU and ensuing impact on the economy. Looking at price action since the Liffe opens, the 10 year debt future was marked down 15 ticks to 122.85 and briefly bounced to 122.90 before fading again, with the low so far at 122.72, effectively tracking moves in Bunds inversely with BTPs, as the former probed a bit deeper towards technical support at a marginal new Eurex base (160.54, -35 ticks) and latter inched a tad further above 121.00 to 121.33 (+102 ticks). Meanwhile, the 3 month strip is 2-3 ticks adrift.

content: Some stabilisation in broad risk sentiment and a partial recovery for some Asia-Pacific stock markets has sapped safe-haven demand for core debt, but the 10 year German benchmark is also conceding ground to recovering BTPs ahead of the EU’s official judgement on Italy’s 2019 budget due at 11.00GMT. The catalyst beyond basic short covering, comments attributed to Deputy PM Salvini suggesting some willingness to revise the fiscal draft, which seems to contradict the rigid stance from the coalition Government and could be perceived as a last ditch conciliatory offering. Nevertheless, BTPs have gapped higher and probed above 121.00 within a 120.79-121.28 range vs Tuesday’s 120.31 close, while Bunds extended losses from an initial 160.71 print and brief uptick to 160.74 to 32 ticks at 160.57 before finding some underlying bids. On that note, market contacts are flagging the 160.54-49 area as nearest chart support, with a gap above the very early Eurex peak up to 160.84 if the tide turns again. However, rebounds may be capped or contained ahead of supply in the form of Eur3 bn Bobls.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

21st November 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks mostly weakened as the global stock rout continued into the region following the losses in US, where the DJIA dropped over 500 points to turn negative YTD and in which energy names were pressured as oil slumped nearly 7%. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) were led lower by spill-over selling seen across the commodity-related sectors, while Wesfarmers shares plummeted nearly 30% after the spin-off of its Coles unit which had its stock market debut today. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) opened with firm losses but then rebounded off their lows with price action choppy amid ongoing trade uncertainty and after criticism from USTR Lighthizer’s report that China has not altered its unfair practices and appears to have conducted further unreasonable actions in recent months.

FTSE

OTHER UK COMPANIES

TalkTalk (TALK LN) – The Co are to relocate their headquarters from London to Manchester, as the Co accelerates progress to shrink their cost-base. (Sky News)

Restaurant Group (RTN LN) – The Co’s takeover of Wagamama has been hampered by its second biggest investor, Columbia Threadneedle, saying they will oppose the deal. (The Telegraph)

Co. expects costs in the high triple digit millions euro range in relation to the Co. split in 2018/19, adding that these costs will weigh heavily on 2018/19 net income and free cash flow. Separately, the Co’s supervisory board has failed to agree on recruiting Bodo Uebber, the outgoing Daimler finance chief. (Newswires)

content:

To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks mostly weakened as the global stock rout continued into the region following the losses in US
  • US Trade Representative Lighthizer released a report regarding China intellectual property and tech transfers which stated that China has not altered its unfair practices
  • UK PM May will discuss the text in Brussels today and will push for parts of her Chequers plan to be recognisable in the document, according to the BBC
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Durable Goods, Weekly Jobs, Existing Home Sales, Uni. of Michigan, DoEs, Japanese CPI, BoE’s Carney, UK PM May to meet with EC’s Juncker

ASIA

Asian stocks mostly weakened as the global stock rout continued into the region following the losses in US, where the DJIA dropped over 500 points to turn negative YTD and in which energy names were pressured as oil slumped nearly 7%. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) were led lower by spill-over selling seen across the commodity-related sectors, while Wesfarmers shares plummeted nearly 30% after the spin-off of its Coles unit which had its stock market debut today. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) opened with firm losses but then rebounded off their lows with price action choppy amid ongoing trade uncertainty and after criticism from USTR Lighthizer’s report that China has not altered its unfair practices and appears to have conducted further unreasonable actions in recent months. Finally, 10yr JGBs failed to benefit from the widespread risk averse tone with price action subdued amid a lack of BoJ presence in the bond market and after the weakness in T-notes as US investors closed positions heading in to Thanksgiving.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9499 (Prev. 6.9280)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer released a report regarding China intellectual property and tech transfers which stated that China has not altered its unfair practices, while it added that it appears that China has conducted further unreasonable actions in recent months and that China has made it clear it will not change its policies in response to initial Section 301 action. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi is expected to visit Madrid next week where infrastructure investment is expected to be a topic for discussions. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May will discuss the text in Brussels today and will push for parts of her Chequers plan to be recognisable in the document, according to BBC Europe Editor Adler. (Twitter)

In a column in the Telegraph, Former Brexit Secretary Raab states that “there is still time to stand up to the bullying tactics from Brussels. But we must change course, or the flame of optimism and opportunity that sparked Brexit will be snuffed out”. (Telegraph)

According to the latest YouGov polling, Brexiteer attempts to remove PM May has backfired. Last week 33% of voters backed Mrs May staying in her post and 47% wanted her to go, however, the latest polling shows that 46% say that she should stay and 34 per cent want her to stand down. (Times)

Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said she made it clear to PM May why she couldn’t support the deal and predicts deal will not get through Commons, while she added it is then up to opposition parties to find an alternative. In related news, there were separate reports that UK PM May explained to Sturgeon that UK is negotiating a deal that works for all parts of the UK, delivering the result of the referendum (BBC/Twitter)

Spanish Foreign Minister Borrell said Spain would not block an independent Scotland from re-entering the EU and that he is worried about unity of the UK. (Telegraph)


FX

FX markets consolidated overnight as the major pairs took a breather from the prior day’s heavy moves in which the greenback advanced on safe-haven demand and as its high-beta counterparts suffered amid the stock sell-off. As such, EUR/USD and GBP/USD languished below the 1.1400 and 1.2800 handles respectively, while commodity-linked currencies were also despondent following the extended declines in oil prices. Elsewhere, JPY-crosses attempted to nurse some of the losses from the risk-averse flows and USD/JPY remained firm with the pair propped up by the strength in the greenback.

BoC's Wilkins said bank will review monetary policy framework in run up to late 2021 and indicated it is open to major changes, while she added it is time to review inflation targeting alternatives. Furthermore, Wilkins added the review will take into account the fact that neutral interest rate is lower than before and that raising inflation level to 3% or 4% would hit people living on fixed incomes. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures found some reprieve during Asia trade with oil underpinned on short-covering and after the latest API inventory report showed a surprise drawdown in headline crude stockpiles, although prices still have far to go to claw back the prior day’s near-7% drop that was attributed to supply concerns, the negative risk sentiment and Trump’s protective approach towards Saudi relations. Elsewhere, gold languished with price action contained as the greenback held on to recent gains, while copper was also subdued and only managed a minimal recovery overnight.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (16 Nov) -1.5mln vs. Exp. +2.9mln (Prev. +8.79mln). (Newswires)

US President Trump said he would like to see oil prices lower and that Saudi Arabia has helped keep oil prices down. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs said slump in oil reflects over supply concerns for 2019 and that technical position factors have exacerbated the volatility, while it also cited low liquidity heading into Thanksgiving as well as broader selling in commodities and cross-assets amid rising growth concerns. (Newswires)

Twitter source noted that a monster storm had shut all of Eastern Canada's crude output but added that one field has now resumed service. (Twitter)


GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said US will remain a steadfast partner of Saudi Arabia, ensuring interest of US, Israel and regional partners, according to statement. Furthermore, Trump stated that Russia and China are set to benefit if US cancels defence contracts with Saudi, while he added that Congress is free to "go in a different direction" on Saudi and that he will only mull ideas "consistent" with US security. Elsewhere, there were later comments from US Senator Graham that there will be strong bipartisan support for serious sanctions against Saudi Arabia and outgoing US Senator Corker demanded that US President Trump makes a determination on Saudi Crown Prince and said Congress will consider law to push the President regarding Saudi Arabia, (Newswires)

North Korea and US in discussions regarding a high-level meeting which could potentially take place on November 27th. (Newswires)
 

US


The treasury complex ended Tuesday’s session mixed; the complex remained bid once again for most of the trading day on a fly to safety as equities extended their sell-off. Some of those gains were pared back as investors closed their positions ahead of Thanksgiving on Thursday when the bond market will remain close. Most of the action was in the front end of the curve were yields were higher by c.2bps at settlement. 2s10 and 2s30s were narrower by c.2bps. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 1+ ticks higher at 119-11.

Fed's Kashkari (Dove, Non-voter) says Fed should pause rate hikes to see how the economy evolves. (Newswires)

US President Trump submitted written responses to Special Counsel Mueller, according to his lawyers. (Newswires)

House Democrats are to investigate Ivanka Trump's emails. (Washington Post)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Global stock rout continues in Asia trade as energy names feel the brunt of the oil price collapse
content:
Asia stocks are lower across the board as the global stock rout continues into the region following the losses in US, where the DJIA dropped over 500 points to turn negative YTD and in which energy stocks were heavily pressured as oil slumped nearly 7%. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) are led lower by spill-over selling seen across the commodity-related sectors, while Wesfarmers shares have also plummeted nearly 30% after the spin-off of its Coles unit which had its stock market debut today. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) opened with firm losses but have since rebounded off their lows to trade choppy amid ongoing trade uncertainty and criticism from USTR Lighthizer’s report that China has not altered its unfair practices and appears to have conducted further unreasonable actions in recent months.

FX markets have consolidated overnight as the major pairs take a breather from the prior day’s heavy moves in which the greenback advanced on safe-haven flows and as its high-beta counterparts suffered amid the stock sell-off. As such, EUR/USD and GBP/USD languish below the 1.1400 and 1.2800 handles respectively, while commodity-linked currencies are also despondent following the extended declines in oil prices. Elsewhere, JPY-crosses attempt to nurse some of the losses from the risk-averse flows and USD/JPY remains firm with the pair propped up by the strength in the greenback.

Finally, 10yr JGBs failed to benefit from the widespread risk averse tone with price action subdued amid a lack of BoJ presence in the bond market and after the weakness in T-notes as US investors closed positions heading in to Thanksgiving.
